I do understand Australia Post's dilemma, but this operation is of great significance in the history of Australia. The 60th anniversary of this operation is important. It is a sad fact of life that there are only two survivors left from Operation Jaywick. If we are forced to wait until another significant anniversary—whether it is 70 or 75 years—there may be no survivors from Operation Jaywick left. It would be appropriate if this very significant military operation were commemorated.

Australia Post does have a wide range of commemorative stamp issues. At the time that the request was rejected for Operation Jaywick, Australia Post issued a commemorative issue for `Champions of the Turf', highlighting five brilliant race horses—Wakeful, Rising Fast, Manikato, Might and Power, and Sunline. I know the racing industry is a great industry and those horses were famous within the industry—and I am not begrudging the issue of that stamp series—but it shows that we can have a whole range of stamps issued for commemorative purposes.

Operation Jaywick and the voyage of the Krait stands as one of the most daring Australian operations of World War II. In early September 1943, the small wooden ship set sail from Exmouth Gulf in Western Australia, carrying 11 Australian Navy and Army personnel and four British personnel. Among them, of course, was leading telegraphist Horrie Young, RAN. Without being detected, the Krait successfully reached an island only 11 kilometres south of Singapore. On 26 September, the commandos used collapsible rubber and canvas canoes to paddle into Singapore's Keppel Harbour. Under the cover of darkness, they attached limpet mines to Japanese merchant vessels before escaping undetected. On the morning of 27 September, the mines exploded, sinking seven ships and striking a major blow against the enemy's supply lines. After resting, the successful raiders then, quite amazingly, paddled another 80 kilometres to rendezvous with the Krait and sail back to Australia. This was an incredible feat of arms by such a small force and worthy of Australia's proud wartime history. It was one of the most amazing feats in World War II.

I appeal to Australia Post to look once again at the possibility of issuing a stamp to commemorate the 60th anniversary of Operation Jaywick and, as part of it, the Z Special Unit Association and the Z Special Unit forces. I know that Mr Horrie Young, his family and all the families of those people who served in Operation Jaywick would greatly appreciate it if Australia Post could, for once, set aside their criteria to only allow the commemoration of anniversaries of 50 years or multiples of 50 years.

talk.start.para: —I am sorry I was a little slow on my feet earlier to second this proposition—I was momentarily distracted. I was to second the proposition on behalf of Mr Kim Wilkie, the member for Swan. The history of the Krait and the Z Special Unit force, of course, resonates very much in the minds of Western Australians, and I know it is a matter that has interested Mr Wilkie for a very long time. He would have dearly loved to have been here to put his point of view forward in support of the proposition that has been raised on the other side of the House by Mr Lloyd.

speech.para: I would agree completely with the proposition that Australia Post could stretch a point and abandon from time to time its celebration of 50th anniversaries to recognise truly significant events in national history and keep the commemoration before the Australian people on a more regular basis. It is worthwhile doing it in this particular case because the engagement of those brave men involved in Operation Jaywick and more generally involved with the special forces—Z Special Unit and other elements of the special forces—in World War II draws our attention in a timely fashion to the critical nature of the strategic significance of the islands to our north, and do so at a point in time when we ought to be thinking about that perhaps a little more deeply that we have in recent years.

There was a time in our nation's history where we—or powers friendly to us—did not control our immediate approaches, and the pressure on Australia was truly massive. An atmosphere of fear, threat and concern existed within this country as we confronted the consequences of a powerful imperial nation thrusting south. We learned then all about the consequences of our nation finding itself cut off or potentially cut off from our main sources of support and we learned all about the significance of the maritime sea routes through the South-East Asian archipelago. Many Australians paid with their lives securing or trying to return control of those areas into friendly hands.

It was always an inspiration to me as a youngster to see year after year at the Anzac Day parades in Western Australia those who participated in Z Special Unit force operations marching proudly. They were always notable because they included that prominent, effervescent, courageous Chinese-Australian, Jack Sue, who always had a prominent role in the marches at that time. He was always an object of some admiration by the Western Australians who watched those marches, and many of them learned the history of this important part of our contribution to World War II by following up in queries in schools and in the public what it was that this proud little band had done that caused them to be such a unique little part of an Anzac Day march.

Most of the veterans of Operation Jaywick died the year afterwards when a similar effort was made which was unsuccessful. Operation Jaywick saw the sinking of some 37,000 tonnes of Japanese shipping in Singapore Harbour and was a real punch in the eye for the Japanese at that time who had assumed themselves invulnerable at sea. Subsequently, the operation was not so successful. In conclusion, I should include the Japanese record of the court proceedings, the evaluation of the enemy of those brave men. It states:

quote.para: With such fine determination they infiltrated into the Japanese area. We did not hesitate to call them real heroes of a forlorn hope. It has been fortunate for us that their intention was frustrated half-way, but when we fathom their intention and share their feelings we cannot but spare a tear for them. The valorous spirit of these men reminds us of the daring enterprise of our heroes of the Naval Special Attack Corps who died in May 1942, in their attack on Sydney Harbour. The same admiration and respect that the Australian Government, headed by the Premier of all of the Australian people, showed to those heroes of ours we must return to these heroes in our presence. When the deed is so heroic, its sublime spirit must be respected, and its success or failure becomes a secondary matter.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to support the motion moved by the Chief Government Whip, the member for Robertson, on Operation Jaywick. I share in his disappointment that Australia Post have declined to accept his overtures for the issue of a special commemorative stamp to acknowledge the 60th anniversary of Operation Jaywick in September next year.

speech.para: Firstly and pre-eminently, I acknowledge the service and bravery of those young Australians so many years ago who played a great part in the defence of our country and took part in a very daring operation. Much to my surprise, a number of Ryan residents who are very heavily involved in the subbranches of the RSLs have flagged this matter with me previously. I am delighted to speak on this motion and to lend my weight to encouraging Australia Post to make an exception to their rules and to acknowledge the 60th anniversary of Operation Jaywick next year.

A number of people in the gallery following question time may not know the complete history of Operation Jaywick and the voyage of the Krait. After my speech I hope that they will be ambassadors for this country, as this is a small part of history we should be very proud of.

The Krait was a former Japanese fishing boat captured during the Malayan campaign and it sailed to Australia following the fall of Singapore and the loss of the Netherlands East Indies during 1942. It was acquired by the allies. Major Ivan Lyon, a British officer who had escaped from Singapore in 1942, hit upon the idea of using this Japanese vessel to mount a commando raid upon Japanese shipping in Singapore. In early September 1943, the small wooden ship set sail from Exmouth Gulf in Western Australia carrying 11 Australian Navy and Army personnel and four British personnel. It is important to acknowledge that the Operation Jaywick raiding party also included three British personnel. I will not name names of all the Australians who played a part in that daring raid, but I salute Mr Horace Young, a constituent of the member for Robertson. As a young Australian and as one of the youngest members of this parliament, I salute his contribution to our country's defence so many years ago.

Operation Jaywick is commemorated not only at the Australian War Memorial, where the ship's log of the Krait is part of the national collection, but also at the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney, where the Krait is on display, in honour of the courage and daring of those who sailed her. This operation has the distinction of being the longest seaborne commando attack on enemy forces in World War II. The Krait is credited with being directly involved in the destruction of more enemy ships in a single engagement than any other Australian naval vessel.

As the member for Robertson has said, he has made representations to Australia Post to honour these brave young Australians when they represented our country in warfare. Regrettably, he was advised that he did not satisfy the criteria against which potential stamp subjects were assessed in order to commemorate such events. I am very disappointed and call upon Australia Post to reconsider their position. Australia Post advise that only anniversaries of 50 years or multiples of 50 years will be considered and that they can only satisfy a small number of requests by members of the public to celebrate and commemorate important events or incidents in our country. It makes sense to some extent but, clearly, as the member for Robertson has said, the racing industry has been acknowledged. Surely, by any measure or criteria, the racing industry falls way short of the bravery of these young Australians so many years ago. They played a part in the defence of our country and upheld the values, traditions and the freedoms that we so cherish today.

I take this opportunity in the House of Representatives, together with my senior colleague and Chief Government Whip, the member for Robertson, to remind Australia Post that commemorative stamps pay tribute to great Australians for the work they did in order to give us the values and freedoms that we have. I strongly urge Australia Post to reconsider. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The heroism, courage and humility of our veterans are well acknowledged and renowned at home and internationally. From Gallipoli to Vietnam and more recently in peacekeeping and efforts in East Timor and Afghanistan, our troops have always punched well above their weight and have gone not in the name of war but always, I believe, in the hope for peace. Australians can be very proud of our men and women who risked everything. Many paid with their lives for the freedom that we enjoy today.

speech.para: During World War II a unit was formed called the Z Special Unit. This unit is often mistakenly referred to as `Z force'. The purpose of this unit was simple: to infiltrate enemy strongholds in enemy territory—dangerous work in any circumstance and sometimes suicidal in nature. This unit was the best trained of our forces, having trained in night and day exercises, commando style raids and expeditions over land and water. So legendary was this Australian special unit that a film was made in the 1990s about their activities and their missions. Anyone who saw the film will understand just how dangerous their missions were. In particular, the film focused on one mission: Operation Jaywick.

While Z Special Unit may have been legendary, they were also extremely secret. So secret were the activities of the Z force that even today little is known of the detail and the men who served during its 182 missions. This was a force of true multiculturalism even before the concept had been invented—and I will talk about the multiculturalism aspect in a moment. The 60th anniversary of Operation Jaywick—the most famous of the missions undertaken—is 26 September 2003. Z Special Unit carried out two raids against enemy shipping in the Japanese-occupied harbour of Singapore. Operation Jaywick was considered at the time to be a suicide mission. The idea of destroying Japanese shipping in Singapore harbour was bold and had the potential to deliver a huge physical as well as a psychological blow to the Japanese forces. So successful was the attack that it resulted in 38,000 tonnes of enemy ships being destroyed. Operation Jaywick was carried out by 10 Australians and four British servicemen who struck at the heart of the Japanese supply line to New Guinea. An interesting fact in relation to the multiculturalism that I referred to is that these highly dedicated veterans were from many backgrounds. While most were Australian, they also included British, New Zealanders, French, Malay, Canadian, Americans, Indonesians and Chinese.

Operation Jaywick enlisted the HMAS Krait—a small fishing boat which travelled some 5,000 miles through enemy infested waters to get to Singapore. The MV Krait was originally known as the Kofuku Maru and had originally belonged to a Japanese fishing firm out of Singapore. During its service history, the MV Krait was used in rescue missions going to the aid of sunken ships along the east coast of Sumatra, and during its service transported more than 1,100 people. Interestingly, the MV Krait was originally restored in 1964 and was being used for training and recreation purposes by the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol. The MV Krait is now part of the Australian War Memorial's collection and is currently on loan to the Australian National Maritime Museum in Sydney, which is a fitting resting place for a vessel that, along with its crew, served Australia so well.

With less than a year before the 60th anniversary of Operation Jaywick in September 2003, the motion before the House seeks to have Australia Post recognise the efforts of the Z Special Unit. This is a worthy request and one that should be considered by Australia Post. Australia Post has a great tradition of celebrating through special edition stamps the achievements of men and women of Australia. It appears that this policy is somehow restricted to a 50-year anniversary only. I have contacted Australia Post and through my office queried the practice and the possibility of a commemorative special stamp series to celebrate Operation Jaywick. I have been told that this is not possible. I simply do not accept that this so-called 50-year unwritten policy is not flexible enough to include other special times in our history that do not fall neatly within the bounds of Australia Post's rules. I urge Australia Post, through this motion, to examine the issue of commemorative stamps and the possibility of including a special edition next year to coincide with the anniversary of Operation Jaywick.

I believe this is an appropriate use of resources and a proper way to celebrate the bravery and service of our veterans. I urge Australia Post to reconsider and to allow for the printing of this special edition. It is something worth while and, as the policy, I am told, is not a written policy, I believe it would easily fall into the category of flexibility and that they could make this stamp happen. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to support my fellow Central Coast member for Robertson in his move to acknowledge the dedicated service and extreme bravery of all Australian veterans involved with the Z Special Unit forces, including those involved in Operation Jaywick in World War II. I can think of no better time to stand with him and the member for Ryan to commemorate the deeds of these brave Australian soldiers, because Australia is again facing a grave threat to our national security. Unlike World War II, this time the enemy is an invisible one, but we still require the same Australian fighting spirit to defend our shores against this impending terror. We again need to harness the same strength of purpose and to draw on the selfless courage that so typified the men involved with Operation Jaywick who sailed aboard the Krait almost 60 years ago.

speech.para: What better time would there be to commemorate their bravery in the face of the enemy than now? What better time would there be to remind Australians that we must stand together, as they did so bravely in the face of their enemy? Above all, what better time would there be to use such a fine example as theirs to draw us all together, to remind us that our heritage is sacred and that our multiracial culture must be woven into one united Australian spirit if we are to truly commemorate the selfless, courageous actions of all who took part in Operation Jaywick and to ensure that the sacrifice they and others have made throughout our history was worth while and justified?

I salute Able Seaman Mostyn Berryman, Seaman Kevin Cain, Lieutenant Edward Carse and Corporal Andrew Crilly. I salute Able Seaman Walter Falls, Seaman Andrew Huston and Seaman Arthur Jones. I salute Seaman Frederick Marsh, Leading Stocker James McDowell, Lieutenant Robert Page and, last but not least—someone who used to reside in my own electorate of Dobell on the Central Coast but who now lives in Robertson—Leading Telegraphist Horace Young. These men were the bravest, many were Australian, and they gave no thought to their own safety as they mounted a commando raid upon Japanese shipping in Singapore's Keppel Harbour and, under the cover of darkness, attached limpet mines to Japanese ships without being detected before escaping. Ultimately, they sank seven ships. It was an incredible feat by such a small force and is most worthy of commemoration.

Their actions were typical of so many brave wartime acts which we must never allow ourselves to forget. They typify the bravery of so many Australians and others throughout our history whose efforts and sacrifices have made Australia the country it is today. Yes, I support the member for Robertson's motion to acknowledge their deeds—we should all support that move—and I support his motion for Australia Post to recognise the 60th anniversary of Operation Jaywick. A stamp of recognition is the absolute least that we can do. Why? Because, if nothing else, Australia needs to be reminded of real heroes now more than ever. Australia Post should really review its 50-year rule for celebrations. This is a most worthy cause and it deserves all our support.

talk.start.para: —This is not the first time that an appeal has been made for some fairness and real recognition for those involved in Operation Jaywick. It is interesting that Prime Minister John Curtin wrote via the Acting Governor-General to try and get justice for a couple of the people involved in Operation Jaywick. I am greatly indebted to Peter Thomson and Robert Macklin for their book Kill the Tiger—an epic Australian war story of bravery and betrayal. This book deals mainly with Operation Rimau, the second operation after Operation Jaywick. A letter on Operation Jaywick from John Curtin, written in September 1944, marked `Top Secret' and addressed to the Acting Governor-General, states:

quote.para: With reference to the communication of Lord Gowrie on 22 May 1944 advising that the bestowal of the Distinguished Service Order on Major Ivan Lyon, the Military Cross on Lieutenant R.C. Page and the Military Medal on Corporals A. Crilley and R.G. Morris have been approved, it will no doubt have come to Your Excellency's knowledge that for certain reasons the promulgation of these awards was suspended pending further investigations.

In the light of information which has since been made available concerning the operation in which these four persons were engaged, it would appear that recognition of a higher standard would be justified in the first two cases, namely Lyon and Page, and I should be obliged if Your Excellency would kindly seek His Majesty's consent for the cancellation of the Distinguished Service Order and Military Cross approved in these cases.

I consider that the services rendered by Major Lyon would be more appropriately recognised by the bestowal on him of the Victoria Cross for great valour and devotion to duty in most hazardous undertakings and that the Distinguished Service Order would be more fitting in Lieutenant Page's case for gallantry, skill and devotion to duty in most hazardous undertakings and I recommend accordingly.

An additional reason for the proposed change in Page's case is that the services rendered by him were similar and equivalent to those rendered by Lieutenant D.K.N. Davidson RNVR, who has already received the Distinguished Service Order on the recommendations of the United Kingdom authorities.

speech.para: That letter was signed by John Curtin. According to the book Kill the Tiger:

quote.para: Curtin recommended Ivan Lyon for the highest valour award in the British Empire—the Victoria Cross—for the Jaywick raid but, we can reveal, the old boy network in London turned it down.

speech.para: We know that there have been a number of injustices with military awards over the years and we have seen a number of them brought to the attention of the House, notably the case of Teddy Sheean, raised by my friend the member for Braddon, Sid Sidebottom. Some of us cannot understand why John Simpson Kirkpatrick never received a VC. Many on Operation Jaywick were not content with what they did on that first strike for freedom so they went back again in Operation Rimau. Of course, none of them survived.

If John Curtin could make an appeal to what was then, unfortunately, a higher authority, then surely we can appeal to Australia Post to review this nonsensical decision. If it were not for the courage and the sacrifice of the men and women of the Australian defence forces who went on operations such as Jaywick and Rimau, we would not be sitting here today in a free, open parliament in one of the greatest democracies in the world. Australia Post might see things a bit differently but, in my view, they do owe commemoration to these people. The decision not to allow this is a bureaucratic one taken by boffins. It is about time they had a good look at themselves. They should have a look at the terms of this motion. It is being dealt with in a very bipartisan way and, like the mover of the motion, I call on Australia Post to review that decision and commemorate the deserving men of Jaywick.

talk.start.para: (Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
—I move:

motion.para: (1) acknowledges the ongoing effects of emotional deprivation suffered by children placed in institutions prior to the mid 1970's;

(2) applauds the public exposure of the misguided policies under which British migrant children and the “stolen generation” of indigenous children were treated and the effects of their treatment in children's institutions evident in adulthood;

(3) recognises that Australian children raised in institutions were denied love and affection, that they were separated from siblings, subjected to harsh discipline and suffered physical and sexual abuse;

(4) recognises that they were conditioned to perform manual work rather than to pursue higher education or develop high level skills and that they were subjected to a deliberate policy to erase any awareness of their biological parents and family; and

(5) calls on the Government to facilitate the full disclosure of the forgotten history of institutionalised children and to respond to the present needs of those generations still suffering the effects of their time in children's institutions.

speech.para: In recent years we have seen inquiries into two areas of institutionalised care of children. We have seen the report of the Senate inquiry into child migration and we have seen the report on the stolen generation. Those inquiries have given us an insight into the misguided treatment of children in care and have revealed the long-term harmful effects of that care. But one stone remains to be turned. Institutionalised care was not restricted to migrant or Indigenous children. Tens of thousands of Australian-born children were raised in institutions and children's homes. They were not always orphaned; many were abandoned by parents unable to cope or were removed from their homes by authorities. They spent a great part of their formative years in religious or state run institutions. Now many of those who were placed in care in decades past have emerged to face the reality of their early years and assess its impact on their adult lives.

To support each other, to share their experiences of their years in children's homes and to seek support and understanding, they have formed networks such as the Care Leavers of Australia Network, whose badge I am proud to stand here and wear today. Their stories have much in common. They tell of being denied love and affection. They tell of being separated from their siblings as part of a deliberate policy to manage their care. They tell of lack of privacy and dignity and of harsh discipline. There are many reports of physical and sexual abuse. There are also stories of kindness and at times misguided compassion, but even at its most benign institutional care made for a hollow childhood. As one of the home children, now in his fifties, says:

quote.para: We were threatened and belittled, there were no bedtime stories, no birthdays, no special occasions. Even Santa Claus abandoned us.

speech.para: Such things are an important part of family life, but managing care in segregated dormitories meant having deliberate policies to erase awareness of biological parents and family. Institutions also had low expectations of those in their care. One articulate and forceful advocate of this issue found her file showed her as `slow but not mentally retarded'. For many of the home children, this became a self-fulfilling prophesy. They were conditioned to perform manual work, and higher education was rarely even considered.

Leonie Sheedy, who is in the gallery today, was one of the home children. Her story gives us some insight into their lives both during and after their years in children's homes. Leonie was made a state ward of Victoria in 1957, at the age of three. She spent the next 13 years at Saint Catherine's Children's Home in Geelong. Leonie has had little or no contact with her eight brothers and sisters over the years. Her reflections in later life sum up the thoughts and feelings of many thousands of home children. She says:

quote.para: Being a parentless person is a most difficult thing. I feel like a second-class member of the community. I feel different, I have no sense of belonging to a long line of extended relatives. My personal feelings on being a state ward are a deep sense of sadness and grief about a loss that is difficult to explain, a loss that is not recognised by the community, let alone governments or agencies, a loss that is different to that of the death of a parent. For state wards there is no mourning. This loss is compounded by a lack of written material to assist people to validate their feelings and emotions and a lack of support services for former state wards.

speech.para: The situation of former state wards was acknowledged in a letter from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's Chris Sidoti, who commented:

quote.para: The responsibility of the state towards these human beings continues beyond the period during which they are in care. Since the state undertook responsibility for them as children it must continue to exercise its responsibilities when they are adults.

speech.para: It is time for governments to facilitate the full disclosure of the forgotten history of institutionalised children and to respond to the present needs of those generations still suffering the effects of their time in children's institutions.

talk.start.para: (Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—At first sight, this motion on institutionalised children seems a worthy contribution to the cause of increasing public awareness of past wrongdoings perpetuated by the three highest estates of our land—the church, the government and the judiciary. These are the very authorities we are taught to believe will protect us from injustice, and all thinking Australians would be appalled at past practices that failed to ensure that children were protected from abuse and would agree, generally, that children should not be separated from their families. But the all inclusive wording of this motion is so broad brush that it detracts from the worthy sentiment of the motion. Not all institutionalised children suffered these deprivations. Not all institutional workers were sadists and paedophiles and it did not all stop in the mid-1970s. Reports inform us daily that individuals in whom we place our trust—teachers, churchmen, doctors, politicians and, indeed, parents—abuse that trust and prey upon the young. It concerns me that the member for Fowler, although undoubtedly well intentioned, has moved a motion that, through its wording, consigns such horrors to the past and isolates the evils to institutionalised care.

speech.para: Members would have received a copy of a handbook on Australian crime from the Australian Institute of Criminology recently. Unavoidably, I must quote selectively from it, but that should not detract from the message. In 2001, there were 16,744 reported victims of sexual assault—a seven per cent rise on the previous year. One in four sexual assaults are perpetrated by a family member, 63 per cent by people known to the victim. Most sexual assaults take place in private residences. Other statistics show that more than 150,000 violent assaults happened in 2001, that males are increasingly likely to be victims of violent assault and that these assaults occur, again, mostly in private residences. Statistically, therefore, there is great danger today—and probably for all time—in allowing children to remain at home in the company of family members. Statistically, children would be far better off in institutions.

Clearly that is a nonsense, just as it is a nonsense to avoid going to bed because that is where most of us die. I do not mean to belittle this motion, but I wonder at its inspiration. In the past few years there have been seemingly limitless apologies issued by national and regional governments, churches and others for past wrongdoings. Parliamentary debates are littered with expressions of sorrow and regret. There is no doubt about this government's commitment to tackling issues of child abuse and exploitation inside and outside Australia, whether by signing international treaties or providing the financial means for young people to leave care and make the transition to independence directly, through the Youth Allowance and special programs such as Reconnect. There are payments available, providing special family support and much better foster care arrangements for children who need care outside their family. Funding of $3.7 million has been provided over three years for a new travel fund, family tracing and counselling services; and funding towards memorials to recognise former child migrants in the Australian community has also been provided.

Few Australians today are unaware of the past abuse of children through migrant schemes, through assimilation policies and through institutional care, but there are still people who want to pick over these past sins through royal commissions and other inquiries. We may learn from the past, but we would be better employed looking to the needs of children today—the abused, the assaulted, the victims of drunken and irresponsible parenting, and the boys and girls growing up in communities where suicide is endemic, where sexual abuse is prevalent and covered up and where adults today conspire to prevent the exposure of rape, incest and family breakdown. In some cases, by claiming some kind of cultural exclusiveness, the perpetrators of these terrible crimes go unpunished. I neither support nor oppose this motion, but I feel that the imperative in this House should be primarily about the future of Australia. It is easy to bemoan the past and, by so doing, to acquit ourselves of the responsibilities of today.

talk.start.para: —I commend the member for Fowler for bringing this motion before the House of Representatives. She has shown great compassion and consideration for institutionalised children who have now grown into adults. I am very disappointed with the contribution that has been made by the member for Solomon. He says that he neither supports nor opposes the motion. You would have to ask why he was speaking on it. This matter has deep compassion and conviction for people who formerly were state wards. We do need to learn from the past. That should guide our actions for the future. If the member for Solomon has concern about sexual abuse and other problems being inflicted on children today, he should take action by bringing similar motions before the House of Representatives so that we can debate them here in the Australian parliament. I am very disappointed that he has found fault in this motion. In fact, at one point he misrepresented the motion. Let me read its first clause:

motion.para: (1) acknowledges the ongoing effects of emotional deprivation suffered by children placed in institutions prior to the mid 1970's . . .

speech.para: It does not talk about all children, but it sensibly recognises the problem that some children, some state wards, have experienced as they have grown into adults. We should recognise this problem. We should congratulate the Care Leavers of Australia Network, CLAN, for its work in providing support, in having a heart and in showing compassion to fellow citizens. CLAN has 320 members around Australia. It has been going for 2½ years. It is a fine support group for former state wards. They are not asking for compensation, but they are asking for recognition. They are not asking for compensation, but they are asking for full disclosure of the facts, full disclosure of what took place in state homes decades ago. They are also asking for counselling assistance and services, and they are asking for fair treatment from, and consideration by, government.

It is true that we have had a lot of public debate about the stolen generation, and rightly so. I await the day when the Australian government says sorry. It is true that we have had a lot of public debate about, and consideration of, the British child migrants. So too we should have debate on, and consideration for, children who were institutionalised, children who were the victims of unsatisfactory practices in state homes and who have now grown into adults. The member for Solomon would not wish that treatment upon his own children. Why is he so heartless to those children who have now grown into adults and simply want some recognition, encouragement and counselling? We all value our family lives. I believe passionately that every day spent together with family is truly a great day. So too we should have compassion for those who have not enjoyed the love of their parents. The love of parents and the love of siblings are the bonds and nourishment that set us up to cope with adult life. The sad truth is that those denied that nourishment and those bonds have difficulties. I pay tribute not only to the member for Fowler but also to Senator Andrew Murray, who has been raising this matter on behalf of CLAN in the Senate. I would like to quote some of his words:

quote.para: Last century it is estimated that 250,000 children were institutionalised in Australia. Through examining this population when older, I would not be exaggerating by stating that 10 years of abuse will often lead to 50 or 60 years of problems . . . The ability to create and maintain satisfying relationships, the capacity for effective parenting, the capability to undertake work, and one's sense of identity, are all fundamentally damaged. Adult lives are plagued with unemployment and welfare dependency, dysfunctional and failed relationships, homelessness and substance abuse, crime and prostitution, and even suicide.

speech.para: Andrew Murray has done the right thing in the Senate; the member for Fowler is doing the right thing here in the House. These are not problems that can be trivialised. These are not problems that can be swept under the carpet. These are not problems that can be rationalised by saying, `Something just as bad is happening today.' This parliament should be against badness. This parliament should be against problems, whether they happened in the distant past or happen today or in the future. We should be against the things that have gone wrong in our society, and we should try to help people who want to solve these problems and make a better world for the future.

CLAN is about that work. It recognises in particular the loss of educational opportunities for institutionalised children. How can we correct that? We should be giving people a second chance in the education system, offering adult and community education courses and opportunities to former state wards. We should help these people with counselling services and, most importantly, government should release the facts. Information costs nothing but, for the people involved, information can be a great source of comfort and a great source for understanding the past and living a better life in the future. This is a good motion. It should not be criticised and it should not be trivialised in any shape or form. For the 250,000 children who were institutionalised in this country, it is a motion of burning importance and significance and should have the support of parliament on both sides of the chamber. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The issues which have been raised in the motion before the House acknowledge some of the circumstances which relate to those children who were institutionalised prior to the 1970s. I am sure that the events which have been detailed relating to many children who were placed in institutional care prior to that period have attracted the sympathy and empathy of members from both sides of the parliament. That is why, for instance, I commend the work carried out by the Senate Community Affairs References Committee which, under the second term of the Howard coalition government, released the report Lost innocents: righting the record. This report specifically looked into the child migration schemes which existed in the last century. The report paid particular attention to the child migration scheme which operated out of England.

speech.para: I have received a personal insight into the handling of child migrants from a constituent of mine who was a child migrant to Australia. I have met Don Coleshills on a number of occasions and have received a first-hand insight into the child migration scheme that operated in the 1930s and 1940s. Mr Coleshills was in foster care in England when at the age of five he was enrolled into the British child migration scheme. He and two of his brothers had been given up for adoption by their mother. Mr Coleshills actually lived with one of his brothers in foster care without knowing that the child he used to play with was in fact his brother. While a family adopted Mr Coleshills's brother, Mr Coleshills became part of the British child migrant scheme and was transported by ship in 1937.

He was sent to a farm school in Bacchus Marsh, where, as he details to me, he was put to work. Some years later he was transferred to Fairbridge Farm School in Molong. Mr Coleshills's recollections of those days paint an environment which was indeed punishing for the children. The children were made to work long hours on farms, without shoes on their feet and with minimal clothing. Discipline on the farm was harsh and public disciplining common, with a pecking order amongst the children which meant that the youngest and the weakest suffered at the hands of older, stronger children. For a six-year-old, this must have been a very tough environment indeed. There was little or no formal schooling, and food was in short supply. We must remember that we are talking about a period when Australia was involved in the Second World War, and many of our resources were focused on conquering the enemy. At this time, Mr Coleshills was incorrectly told that he was an orphan and that he did not have any living relatives. He was deprived of the basic support and love that epitomises the values which we hold so dear in today's society.

Despite such difficult circumstances, Mr Coleshills secured a job in the kitchen of the farm school in Molong, and at the age of 12 he took over cooking the meals for 125 child migrants and 25 staff at the institution. A few years later, this experience helped him to gain a cooking apprenticeship at a hotel in Temora. He went on to cook for shearers and forge a successful life, which included becoming the shire president of Phillip Island. But despite his success in life, Mr Coleshills experienced tremendous grief, insecurity and emptiness because of his separation from his family and the environment in which he was placed on his arrival in Australia. He told me of his loneliness, his inability to trust people, the scars from his time at the farm school and his lack of identity. Not knowing who he was and where he had come from left a tremendous emptiness in his life.

To some extent, those emotions have been partly reconciled through the assistance of the Fairbridge Foundation and a friend who was a historian. Over time, they revealed that in fact he was not an orphan and that he had eight brothers and a sister living in England. Collectively, they have over 80 siblings. In recent years, Mr Coleshills made three trips to Great Britain since he established that he had family over there. He discovered that his father, who was a policeman, and his mother had both remarried and had children. He even found the unmarked grave of his mother. But returning to England was a very emotional experience. The years of wondering who he was and how he belonged were now accompanied by tremendous insecurity about how he would be received by his relations in England. Not all of his brothers accepted who he was and made an effort for a reunion with Mr Coleshills. Mr Coleshills described the experience as `like walking on eggshells'.

Mr Coleshills today is the vice-president of the child migrant association and, despite his pain, acknowledges that the government has gone some way to addressing the issues which confront the association's members right across Australia. While it is true that we cannot change history, it is important that we acknowledge the concerns of child migrants and look forward with some practical support and assistance. To that end I welcome the additional commitment which this government has made with regard to the child migrant scheme. As the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Gary Hardgrave, announced earlier this year, a package of $3.7 million will allow a number of measures to be implemented to assist child migrants. The essential element in this issue is that we continue to look forward. Rather than dwell on the difficulties of the past, it is important that we look to the future and take a positive outlook with regard to people who were in this situation.

talk.start.para: —I am indeed pleased to have the opportunity today to speak to this private member's motion brought forward by the member for Fowler on institutionalised children. I want to congratulate her for doing so. Given the debate that has already ensued, I want to draw particular attention to paragraphs (3) and (4) of the motion, which I think some members on the other side have missed. They are:

speech.para: (3) recognises that Australian children raised in institutions were denied love and affection, that they were separated from siblings, subjected to harsh discipline and suffered physical and sexual abuse;

(4) recognises that they were conditioned to perform manual work rather than to pursue higher education or develop high level skills and that they were subjected to a deliberate policy to erase any awareness of their biological parents and family . . .

I refer to those paragraphs because I strongly disagree with the sentiments of the member for Solomon. The member for Cowper, who just spoke, concentrated primarily on migrant children—which is a legitimate subject but not the subject of this motion. What we are actually speaking about here are children who, in the period leading up to the seventies, were made wards of the state, for example, and then, as a result of their circumstances, thrown into institutions. Paragraphs (3) and (4) of this motion clearly describe the sort of atmosphere, future and existence that they had during that time. That is what we are really talking about here today.

The group CLAN, the Care Leavers of Australia Network, has been formed—primarily with the hard work of Leonie Sheedy and Joanna Penglase—to try and bring attention to the issue. I thank them for it. I am one of probably millions of typical Australians who have not really thought about this before. We have heard about the British migrant children's experience and we have heard about the stolen generation's experience—both have been debated at length. I agree with my colleagues who spoke previously that the day the apology comes will be a good one. I have to confess quite openly that I had not spent the time to think seriously about what had happened to the category of children we are speaking about on this motion today.

I had the pleasure a few weeks ago of meeting Leonie and Joanna. They paid me a visit here in Canberra, and we sat and talked for an hour or more about what they are actually about. They told me about the sort of work they are doing, the sort of recognition they are looking for and the sorts of issues that they and their colleagues in CLAN are facing, as well as all those hundreds and thousands of other people out there who have similar backgrounds. I really puzzle over how anyone could object to, or be critical of, this motion because it is really saying: `Can we just think about this for a minute? Can we carefully consider the sorts of needs these people have, built upon the past that they have come from and built upon the fact that other categories of people have in fact had some attention drawn to them?' That has probably encouraged the formation of CLAN in recent years. According to the CLAN background paper:

quote.para: Church or charitable Homes and institutions, however, in this era were the most common form of out-of-home care for children without viable family. Public inquiries such as the one which resulted in Queensland's 1999 Forde Report have shown that residential care all too often involved high levels of sexual, physical and emotional abuse. What is less well known is that the policies and practices that were characteristic of the management of residential Homes in this earlier time resulted in children feeling completely abandoned and emotionally neglected, cut off from both family and community ties ...

speech.para: Much has been done up until now about addressing similar needs for children who were adopted out, where there was no connection between their current family situations and their past, and I applaud that. We are asking for the government to similarly consider that there are a number of people out there who have lost that background, who have that lack of connection, and they are no less important than other categories of people for whom we have done some work as a community. Both of these women from CLAN said to me, as the shadow minister for ageing: `Many of these children are now starting to move up through the baby boomer generation into their older years. When they get to that point and they have additional needs, it might be useful if we know that this background actually exists for them as well.' I really want to enforce and support the motion before the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is clearly evident that all levels of government have a moral responsibility to ensure that our children are adequately protected from abuse and emotional trauma, and I acknowledge the contributions already made by the member for Solomon and the member for Cowper in particular in relation to this debate on institutionalised children. This responsibility especially exists where the children are under the care of the state. Even though child protection is a state and territory responsibility, the Commonwealth government is concerned about abuse of children in care and the long-term devastating impact that such incidents have on the quality of life of children. Another aspect that causes severe emotional turmoil is where a child grows up without knowing, or is separated from, their parents. Even though it may be necessary for children to be cared for outside the family, I share the member for Fowler's concern that there is a need to encourage children to maintain a connection with their families in appropriate circumstances. I also recognise that a percentage of children brought up as state wards, foster children and children of the child migration scheme in the early 1930s to 1960s received inadequate treatment while they were in care.

speech.para: The government has taken a number of positive steps to address the issues of child abuse in state care. These policies have focused on prevention and early intervention strategies, such as the implementation of the Australian Council for Children and Parenting, the National Child Protection Clearing House, early intervention parenting projects, Youth Allowance, youth activity services and family liaison workers. The Commonwealth, in conjunction with the states, has also agreed to work towards a national plan for foster care and children that will aim to enhance the support services available for Australia's 17,000 children in foster care and their foster families.

It has been suggested previously that the government should hold a royal commission into the abuse of children in care. Generally, however, a broad national inquiry would be unlikely to provide comprehensive benefits or enhance the government's capacity to address these issues effectively in the future. Nevertheless, the government continues to play a key role in designing new initiatives that help prevent child abuse and neglect and that support parents in their parenting role. Children are a special part of our Australian society and are a special part of the electorate of Dickson. Dickson is a vibrant and energetic community comprising many young and happy families. All of the children that I have met in my electorate—whether young students at the All Saints Catholic School and Preschool at Albany Creek or senior students at Northpine Christian College—have fostered a love of learning and a love of life. Unfortunately, though, this is not always the case.

Part of my role in this place is to represent the people of Dickson on a number of committees. One of the most beneficial committees that I have been a part of during this parliament is the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. The terms of reference of that committee have seen us investigating the vast problem of both illicit and licit drugs within our society, and in particular the effects those drugs have on young people and the social effects and other effects they have on our community. Once that committee has handed down its report on the current inquiry, we will be investigating ways to improve the health and wellbeing of children. The outcome of that inquiry will be of great benefit to the families in Dickson and across the country. The inquiry will focus on examining ways to enhance parenting capacity and develop child and family friendly communities—communities that are safe. This is what is important to the people of Australia.

The issue must also be looked at in terms of the capacity of our community to assist in decreasing the trend of increased criminal activity, particularly by young offenders. Better families mean better children, and better children mean less youth related criminal activity. Not all children are potential criminals but for the minority who have that potential we must do what we can to remove them from such a vulnerable position. I know that the people of Dickson will wholeheartedly support any step taken to help reduce crime, particularly crimes committed by our youth. I am proud of my fellow Dickson residents for the interest they have always demonstrated when given an opportunity to improve our community, and I ask them to be a part of this process and contribute to the work of this committee by making submissions and suggestions and helping the elected representatives to understand the issues involved at the grassroots level. In particular, the committee will look at what is needed to strengthen family relationships, parenting skills and confidence, and the committee will determine what services for children and parents are lacking and the ways all tiers of government can help.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for private members' business has expired. The debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—During the time that is available to me in this grievance debate, I want to address the issue of disability services, particularly in relation to people with disabilities who work. I received a copy of a letter from Mr Alan Chapman, one of my constituents, which touches on an issue that many families who have a child with a disability would experience. I want to read the letter that he wrote to the Prime Minister. He said:

quote.para: Dear Prime Minister

Some weeks ago The Weekend Australian ran a feature on companies that had received the Prime Minister's Award for taking a pro-active role in employing people with disabilities. I'm sure you are proud to be associated with the recognition given to these companies.

You will no doubt be aware that the Commonwealth's Disability Pension is means tested and those people with a disability and fortunate enough to be able to hold down full-time employment therefore receive no Federal or State Government assistance whatsoever. Let me repeat that statement. They receive NOTHING.

I am sure you will also be aware that people with disabilities more often than not incur additional living expenses that are directly related to their disability. For example, my son Nicholas has limited mobility and although he is able to work full-time, he can only do so provided he is able to use his car for travel to and from work.

Attached is a summary of my son's circumstances, together with the grounds under which he intends to lodge a claim for work-related expenses with the Australian Taxation Office. This information has previously been provided to your Treasurer and Minister for Family and Community Services.

This may cause some difficulty for your Government, as a successful claim (including a claim for tax overpaid in previous years) could have significant implications for your Government's Budget. I have no idea how many disabled people there are in similar circumstances to my son, but if my son's claim is successful and others then make a claim the amount involved could be substantial.

It is grossly unfair and probably discriminatory that a disabled person working full-time is unable to claim as a tax expense those work-related costs associated with their disability. The probable discriminatory aspect of this issue is also being reviewed under current Equal Opportunities legislation and may be the subject of a separate claim under that legislation.

This is not a grab for Commonwealth dollars for the sake of seeking a windfall and the intention to reduce the claim by the amount of avoided public transport charges will reinforce that position. It is a genuine attempt to get the rules changed for people with disabilities. Pursuing this claim through the Australian Taxation Office will, I hope, get everyone's attention focussed on this issue.
I would welcome and appreciate any comments you may have on this matter.
Yours sincerely
Alan Chapman

speech.para: Attached to the letter to the Prime Minister is a page entitled `Background to Proposed Claim'. I want to run through it, as Mr Chapman has provided it to me. He says:

quote.para: Nicholas is 27 years old and has cerebral palsy. He works full time and will soon move into his own apartment as a further step towards fully independent living. However, as a result of means testing he receives no Commonwealth or State Government assistance whatsoever even though his disability causes additional work related expenditure that a non-disabled person would not incur.
The following therefore describes the basis on which he intends to claim work related expenses as a tax expense.

1. Tradesmen are entitled to claim the cost of tools as a work related expense. The principle would appear to be no tools, no work and no work means no income. And no income means no tax income. There is also an “equalisation” principle involved as well. For example, a tradesman spending $2,000 on tools and earning $30,000 per year would only have $28,000 income, but would still be taxed on the full $30,000. This would be unfair, as an individual not required to provide their own tools and earning the same $30,000 would retain the full amount as income.

2. Individuals are also entitled to claim travel to their principal place of business as a work related expense, where they are required to transport bulky items or equipment in order to be able to carry out their work.

3. Finally, an individual attending a work-related further education course is able to claim the cost of the course and travel as a work related expense. This benefits the individual and the Commonwealth, since maintaining or improving an individual's employment prospects means ongoing and (hopefully) higher income, which, in turn, means ongoing or higher tax income.

Nicholas' disability means a significant additional cost (amongst others) incurred in maintaining his ability to keep working is the need to drive to work, as alternative means of transport are beyond his limited mobility. As a result, it is intended to claim the cost of travel to and from work as a work-related expense. The logic behind this has already been recognised by the Australian Taxation Office in the three examples above, namely:

speech.para: · No tools, no work. In this case driving his car to work is the “tool” that enables Nicholas to carry out his employment. And the same income equalisation principle applies as well.
· He is required to carry a bulky (ie. difficult to manoeuvre on public transport) item to his principal place of business. The difficult to manoeuvre item is himself!
· Like self-education expenses, being able to maintain his employment means ongoing income for him and ongoing tax income for the Commonwealth.

quote.para: The method of calculating the claim is yet to be determined and will establish if the appropriate method is the ATO's mileage allowance or depreciation method. However, it is intended that the claim will be LESS the cost of public transport as this is a cost my son would have had to pay, if it was not for his disability. It is also intended to lodge a claim for previous tax years.

speech.para: This letter has gone to the Prime Minister. Copies have been sent to the Treasurer; the Hon. Senator Nick Minchin, the Minister for Finance and Administration; Senator Amanda Vanstone, the Minister for Family and Community Services; and me, as his local member. I do not necessarily agree with everything that Mr Chapman has had to say, but I recognise and understand the issues he raises. I recognise them because, as a person with a disability, I know that what he says is true. Perhaps I should declare a pecuniary interest here, but I will not be claiming any of my disability related costs as a tax deduction. But for Mr Chapman and so many people like him this is a real issue.

One of the things that a person with a disability has throughout life is increased costs in a whole range of areas. For instance, many people who have to buy a car need to buy an automatic because that is the only way to effectively fit in a hand control. That is an additional cost. A lot of people with disabilities cannot buy clothes off the peg. Often they have to have clothes tailored. This applies to shoes as well. There are so many areas in which people with disabilities face extra costs, and this places an extra burden on them or their families.

The point is that, while we might not agree with everything that Mr Chapman has said, he made a number of good points. We should be doing everything in our power to provide incentives for, and assistance to, those people with disabilities who can work to go out and work. It is not just a matter of finance, income or paying taxes; it has a heck of a lot to do with self-esteem. I know a number of people who have a range of disabilities. Some of the people I know who work have very severe disabilities. They require assistance to get to the workplace. They cannot drive, and they require help. Often that help has to come from families or from other volunteer carers. Interestingly enough, when some of these people get into the workplace, providing that it is accessible, they can do a full day's work and are very productive employees. I ask the Prime Minister and others who have been put on this list to have a good look at this letter. Even if they do not agree with the issues, I hope they will at least give a positive response to Mr Chapman and to the many people with disabilities who are finding it difficult to retain a place in the workplace because of costs, as well as to those who are very keen to get into the workplace.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on behalf of a mate and a constituent, Dr Geoffrey Vaughan, former Deputy Vice-Chancellor of Monash University, former head of the Therapeutic Goods Administration, currently Chair of the Cooperative Research Centres Committee and a member of the Industry Research and Development Board. Dr Vaughan believes that his reputation, honesty and integrity have been unfairly attacked. His letter to me of 19 November reads:

quote.para: Dear Bob,

Senator Boswell launched an unwarranted attack on my reputation in the Senate on Tuesday 12 November 2002. I refer you to the Senate Hansard and the Second Reading Debate on Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002.
Senator Boswell attacks me with statements which are completely false and without foundation. He has attacked my reputation, honesty and integrity.

I have enclosed copies of two letters I have sent to the President of the Senate to clear my name from impropriety and to restore my reputation. I should like you as my local MP to do everything possible to clear my name and right the injustice which has been done.
I would also appreciate receiving advice from you as to what further actions I can take to clear this matter from the public record.
Yours sincerely,
(Dr) Geoffrey Vaughan

speech.para: His letter to the President of the Senate, the Hon. Paul Calvert, dated 13 November 2002, reads:

quote.para: Dear President Calvert,

I have noted from Hansard, 12 November 2002, that Senator Boswell has raised “serious questions of conflict of interest” in relation to my membership, as Chair, of the Cooperative Research Centres (CRC) Committee and as a member of the Industry Research and Development (IR&D) Board. Senator Boswell has implied impropriety in relation to my activities on these bodies. He has linked the conflict of interest to my position as a Director of BresaGen Limited and a perceived association with Professor Alan Trounson.
I should like to bring to your attention the following matters:

· The activities of the CRC Committee are under continuous review of a probity auditor appointed by the Commonwealth. The committee considers matters of conflict of interest as a key agenda item at every meeting of the committee.

· I have declared my directorships, all shareholdings, and all other areas of potential conflict to the Department of Education, Science and Training (and to the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources in the case of the IR&D Board) and this information is held on the appropriate Departmental registers.

· The CRC Committee is a committee of advice to the Minister for Science. The Committee does not make direct grants to applicants, through its terms of reference it only gives advice to the Minister who is responsible for all funding decisions.
· The CRC Committee has never received an application for funding involving BresaGen Limited.

· Senator Boswell has stated that “Vaughan was also appointed to the industry R&D board that subsequently gave Vaughan's own company, BresaGen, a grant of $4.9 million to find a stem cell therapy cure for Parkinson's”. The facts are that BresaGen was awarded a START Grant in May 2000 and I was appointed to the Board in September 2000.

· Whenever any matter related to BresaGen is discussed at the IR&D Board my conflict is declared by me in advance and I remove myself from the meeting. I do not receive any related agenda papers, I do not participate in any discussion, I am not involved in any way in any decision making, and I do not receive the minutes of the particular agenda item.

· Senator Boswell has linked me to Professor Trounson because I held the position of Deputy Vice-Chancellor of Monash University. I resigned from Monash more than 10 years ago. Since that time I have held Australian Government and industry appointments.

· Senator Boswell has linked my name in the debate to other people he has identified, namely Peter Jonson, Alan Trounson, and Bob Moses. I have never had any personal commercial interests or dealings with any of these people.
I would be pleased if you would copy this letter to members of the Senate and have it included in the official record.
Yours sincerely,
(Dr) Geoffrey Vaughan

speech.para: A final letter, again to the President of the Senate, the Hon. Paul Calvert, dated 19 November, reads:

quote.para: Dear President Calvert,

When I wrote to you on 13 November 2002 I was receiving medical treatment which resulted in surgery on 15 November. Because of this, my letter had been written somewhat in haste and should have included further information. I should now like to bring this information to your attention in the hope that my reputation can be restored following Senator Boswell's attack on me in the Debate on 12 November 2002 related to the Research Involving Embryos Bill.
Further to the information previously submitted I should like to make the following additional comments:

speech.para: · The START grant awarded to the “Trounson company” Copyrat was made under delegation by the Biological Committee of the IR&D Board. I am not a member of that Committee and played no role whatsoever in any part of the process.

· It is implied that I was associated with the Biotechnology Innovation Fund (BIF) award to the “Trounson company” IngenKO through my membership of the IR&D Board. Again, the Board delegated, through its legislated powers, the full operation and allocation of BIF awards to the Biological Committee of the Board. I am not a member of the Biological Committee and thus played no part in the award of any grant to IngenKO, nor indeed in any other award or grant of BIF Funds.
· I have never been involved with the funding bodies responsible for the award of the Biotechnology Centre of Excellence, Major National Research Facilities, ARC or NHMRC grants.

quote.para: The implications that I have abused a conflict of interest because of my role on the CRC Committee, as a member of the IR&D Board, as a Director of BresaGen Limited, or in my previous role of Deputy-Vice Chancellor of Monash University are without foundation and are an unwarranted attack on my reputation, honesty and integrity.
I would again be pleased if this letter could be copied to all members of the Senate and again I ask that this additional information be included in the official record.

speech.para: I will attest to the integrity, honesty and reputation of Dr Vaughan. I have known him for many years. I worked with him closely when we worked together with two Labor governments—a state Labor government and the federal Labor government—in order to establish a new campus of Monash University in Berwick in my electorate. He is a fine gentleman. I hope this helps to clear his name. I thank the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to have the opportunity today to rise and speak on a subject of immense importance to Australia's future—the operation of our higher education system. Whilst I am pleased to have this opportunity, I am distressed that there is a need to raise my concern. It is my genuine hope that our university systems are managed by all governments in a manner that is beyond criticism and beyond reproach. Unfortunately, that is not the situation under the current minister and the current government. Staff, students and intuitions have lost, and lost badly, under this government. This loss and neglect of our higher education system is occurring at a time when we have a greater reliance on education than ever before. Our economic health and, indeed, our social health as a nation depend on our ability to educate ourselves, to educate ourselves continually, and, more importantly, to educate our children.

speech.para: As we recently celebrated 30 years since the election of the Whitlam government, I was moved to reflect upon my own family's ability to have gone to university because of the measures that were introduced. If the Whitlam government had not made those sorts of changes, five members of my family would have had no hope of ever affording a university education at one of the fine institutions in my electorate of Chisholm—Monash University. I am blessed with having two higher education institutions within my electorate: Monash University at Clayton and the city campus of Deakin University at Burwood. These institutions make an invaluable contribution to the education of both younger and older Victorians and to the communities in which they are located. But these institutions are not receiving the support from this government to enable them to maintain the diversity and quality of educational experiences they wish to deliver.

Responses from the minister to questions that I placed on notice earlier this year make interesting reading. These figures show that at Deakin University in 1994 there were 12,705 HECS funded undergraduate places and in 2001 there were 13,372 places. This is an increase of 5.25 per cent in non fee paying undergraduate places over eight years. At the same time, the number of domestic full fee paying undergraduates has increased by nearly 300 per cent since the introduction of full fee paying places in 1998. Figures on Monash University are very similar: a 2.4 per cent increase in HECS places and a massive increase in full fee paying places of 317 per cent. That is for domestic places. This is a stark reminder of the increasing unfairness of the policies of the current government in relation to higher education. The huge proportional increases in the number of full fee paying students give an advantage to those who are financially able to pay up front and disadvantage those who are not.

There appears to be no bright light at the end of the tunnel. We can expect the costs of higher education in Australia to increase even more. The other great disadvantage of this is that students who are getting lesser scores than other students can get into full fee paying places whilst students who get better marks cannot get in. One case was brought to my attention of a delightful student last year who was 0.2 per cent off getting into law at Monash University. She had won the Monash law prize, but she was 0.2 per cent off getting into the university on her TER score and she did not get in. Had she been a full fee paying student, she could have got in with 10 fewer marks. Had she not been the youngest of nine children, her parents may have been able to afford to do that. Sadly, they could not.

Such disadvantage in the higher education sector appears to be growing. An article in the Age on 4 December, nicely titled `Cost of university degrees set to increase', gives a stark example of a situation developing in that sector where those financially well off can afford to send their children to university and those who are not well off will not be able to send their children to university. The article states:

quote.para: Education Minister Brendan Nelson's plans for higher education reform look likely to increase the cost of a university degree. Prime Minister John Howard and senior members of the government have been presented with Dr Nelson's completed reform package, which is widely tipped to deregulate the sector, allowing universities scope to set their own fees for courses.

The package will be considered as part of next year's budget process but is unlikely to include any funding increase for universities, with Treasurer Peter Costello having ruled out new spending on anything other than defence. Questioned on the contents of the package yesterday, Dr Nelson repeatedly refused to assure students and their families that the cost of a university degree would not increase as a result of his plans.

speech.para: I believe our higher education system is less fair than it should be. And it appears that the Minister for Education, Science and Training is determined to make it unfairer still. At the same time as having increased the cost of university education, the government, through its inadequate funding, is causing a reduction in choice at universities. When reading the Age on Saturday, I came across an article titled `Uni staff face job losses in cost cuts'. It states:

quote.para: Monash University's—

speech.para: my old alma mater, which is in my electorate—

quote.para: arts faculty faces a deficit of $3.6 million next year. The dean, Homer Le Grand, has instituted a staff freeze and sent a memo to university employees warning of targeted redundancies.

Professor Le Grand yesterday said government funding to universities had been steadily dropping and HECS revenue was not being reinvested in the sector. He said that despite the staff freeze, the university was considering new appointments in strategic areas and he hoped to avoid a repeat of the deep cuts in 1988 that meant 55 arts academics left the university.

speech.para: The article goes on to quote Mr Matthew McGowan, a fine individual who is the Secretary of the National Tertiary Education Union in Victoria. Mr McGowan said:

quote.para: Federal Government funding cuts have created a dynamic that supports and expands profitable areas and diminishes expensive areas, even when they are of great significance to our nation's cultural heritage.
Monash built its reputation in the arts and sciences, which are the very areas most at risk in the current climate.

speech.para: I admit to having a personal interest in the operation of the arts faculty, having been a graduate of Monash University. But I think that this is a concern that we all should share, because it is simply not possible for our universities to continue to deliver the varied and high-quality education that we expect of them while cutting staff and reducing choice.

There has been a recent report on the absolutely scandalous reduction in the education of students in Asian languages. Given where our country is located, I think this of stark concern, and we need to explore this. Something like three students are currently studying Japanese at higher university level within my electorate. That is just absurd. We will have no ability to engage with our neighbours if we cannot communicate with them. We are fairly bad at learning languages in our country anyway, with a stark belief that everybody speaks and understands English, but there is an absolute crisis in the teaching of Asian languages.

Within the areas of arts and science at Monash University we have seen crisis after crisis, some brought on by university management, sadly, but a lot brought on by this government starving universities of funding. There does not seem to be any end in sight. Coupled with this is the inability of staff to actually undertake research because they are spending their entire life teaching huge numbers of students. Yes, that is their primary focus, but universities are also meant to be places where basic research is done. If we do not have basic research in this country, we will not have growth in future employment. Without looking at these things we will have no future for our children. I despair, because where are we going to go and where are they going to go? We used to fashion ourselves as the clever country, the country that was going to embark upon new ideas. This just seems to have been thrown out the door by this government and totally harshly disregarded. It is a tragedy, and it is a tragedy we cannot afford to have. More importantly, it is a tragedy our children cannot afford to have.

We have a right to expect better from our universities and it is the responsibility of the government, in particular the minister for education, to make sure that our universities are resourced in a way that guarantees that quality will be maintained. We cannot continue to say that somehow somebody else will pick up the tab, students paying full fees will pick up the tab, industry will pick up the tab or somebody else will pick up the tab. At the end of the day it is a primary responsibility of the government to look after the education of our nation, and that is education across the board. I do not downplay other areas of education. I believe another area that needs looking at is TAFE. The TAFE sector is well represented in my electorate. But universities need to be maintained and they need to be better resourced. I accept that this government and this minister in particular do not have a belief in the importance of universities, but I believe that they are important, and the least the government and the minister could do is ensure that we are not going backwards. Currently our universities, their standards and their funding are going down the drain.

talk.start.para: —The Queensland Minister for Public Works and Housing recently told the Queensland parliament that the public housing waiting lists were at an all-time high in Queensland.
